CERTIFICATES.TITLE: Guidelines For Accreditation of Balint Leaders
CERTIFICATES.TEXT1: Proposed by the Leadership Task Force Approved by Council in Salzburg, Austria – 14 May, 2016
CERTIFICATES.TEXT2: These guidelines are intended as parameters for national societies to consider when drawing up their criteria for accreditation. National societies will want to define periods of sufficient lengths of time for being in a Balint Group, for instance. Societies need to be aware that it is equally important for psychiatrists and psychotherapists to acquire experience of leading Balint Groups before becoming accredited, as it is for GPs. And that the pathway for psychiatrists and psychotherapists will be different to the pathway for GPs.

LIST.1: Leaders should have appropriate basic professional training.
LIST.2: Leaders must have prior experience of being in a Balint Group for a sufficient* length of time.
LIST.3: Leaders should have co-led with an accredited leader as part of their training who is invited to provide a report/reference to the accrediting society.
LIST.4: Leaders should have a supervisor who has sufficient** knowledge of their work to be able to provide a report/reference to the accrediting society.
LIST.5: Leaders should be evaluated prior to accreditation according to the following criteria:
LIST.6: Leaders should receive adequate and continuing supervision.

SUBLIST.1: that they encourage the development of a safe and free environment within the group and are aware of the importance of protecting the boundaries of the group
SUBLIST.2: that they focus the work on an exploration of the doctor-patient relationship rather than seeking solutions or teaching
SUBLIST.3: that they are open to learning about their personal style in leading a group and aware that their attitudes and responses will influence the dynamics of the group
SUBLIST.4: that they have an awareness of group processes and unconscious processes that are likely to affect the primary task of the group
SUBLIST.5: that they recognize that becoming an accredited Balint leader is a not an end but a beginning

CERTIFICATES.*: * to be determined by accrediting societies
CERTIFICATES.**: ** may not be possible at present in some societies

LEADS_DESC.TITLE: International Balint Group Leader Training Program
LEADS_DESC.MODULE1: Balint group training for self-awareness and professional development
LEADS_DESC.MODULE1_DESC:
- 72 academic hours - 4 seminars, 18 academic hours each - 6 months

(BG attendance as a group participant)
LEADS_DESC.MODULE2: BG leaders training. BG theory and practice
LEADS_DESC.MODULE2_DESC:
- 96 academic hours - 6 seminars, 16 academic hours each – 1 year

(Balint work as a leader and co-leader under the guidance of a supervisor, methodology workshop
LEADS_DESC.MODULE3: Master class by foreign (German, British etc.) BG leaders
LEADS_DESC.MODULE3_DESC:
- 30 academic hours - 2 seminars, 14-16 academic hours each

Participation in Germany- and Great Britain-hosted seminars possible by prior arrangement

Participation in master classes held on the sidelines of conferences possible
LEADS_DESC.MODULE4: Independent work as a BG leader and co-leader
LEADS_DESC.MODULE4_DESC:
- 72 academic hours - at least 9 months

Work report:Group registration (a list of participants and their e-mails sent to the trainer)

BG leader’s work supervision-3 supervisionsduring Module 4

Supervision can be conducted via Skype
LEADS_DESC.TEXT1: Combining of seminars possible for regional specialists(if specifically requested)
LEADS_DESC.TEXT2:
On completion of training

the specialist is awarded a PPL Balint Group Leader Certificate as well as Moscow Balint Society Certificate. The latter allows the specialist to participate in international events, which require accreditation with the national Balint society.
LEADS_DESC.TEXT3:
To qualify for a certificate, the specialist must undergo a total of

- 100 hours of psychotherapy (personal therapy)

- 30 hours of psychotherapy practice supervision with certified specialists.
LEADS_DESC.TEXT4: <strong><u>The BG Leader Certificate allows the specialist to conduct the 1st module of the BG Leader Training Program (4 seminars – 72 hours).
LEADS_DESC.TEXT5:
Further training

(14 seminars with foreign BG leaders) allows specialists to teach the full course of BG Leader Training Program as well as provides the status of the International Practice Balint Group Leader.

GROUPS_DESC.TITLE: About Balint Groups
GROUPS_DESC.CAPTION: The Balint group is a classic method of group training research work, used to prevent the professional burnout of specialists in helping professions.
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH1:
The central object of the research in the classical Balint group is the 'doctor-patient', 'psychologist-client', etc. relationship.

The analysis of these relationships provides an opportunity to more fully understand the client in all the variety of his connections and interactions with the real world, to gain an alternative perspective of the relationship with the patient, thus improving the skills of professional communication and helping to overcome crises in personal and professional development.
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH2: The first training seminars for general practitioners were organized in the 50s in London’s famous Tavistock Clinic by Michael Balint, a psychoanalyst of Hungarian origin. In his famous classic work, The Doctor, his Patient and the Illness, Balint outlined the basics of such seminars, with the method named after him.
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH3:
The Balint group work is aimed to:

increase competence in professional interpersonal communication;

boost awareness of personal blind spots blocking professional relations with the patient;

expand ideas about the treatment process (as opposed to doctors’ “apostolic” attitude);

enable psychological prophylaxis of the group participants, based on the possibility of working out “unsuccessful” cases in the environment of collegial support
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH4: <strong>Standard rules of Balint group work: confidentiality, sincerity, personal responsibility, respect for the opinion of others, the rule of 'stop,' non-use of psychological and medical terms, no criticism or advising.
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH5:
The objectives of Balint group work:

- to encourage physicians to value their interpersonal skills and learn to understand their limits,

- to improve the doctors’ perception and understanding of patients’ communication,

- to boost the doctors’ awareness of their 'blind spots' in communicating with patients,

- to enable psychological prophylaxis of burnout syndrome.
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH6:
The Balint group helps answer the following questions:

- Why do doctors ignore a lot in their relationships with patients?

- Why are they often unable to understand their feelings occurring in the course of these relationships?

- How are resistance, defense and transference occurring under the influence of feelings and emotions related to patients manifested in doctors?

and how it affects:

- communication with patients;

- the effectiveness of therapeutic contact;

- professional health of the doctor.
GROUPS_DESC.PARAGRAPH7:
BG work results in:

- improvement of the perception and understanding of communication with the patient,

- awareness of the therapeutic significance of interpersonal relationships and their boundaries,

- expansion of the repertoire of communicative stereotypes,

- increased awareness of 'blind spots,' psychological defenses. Transference and counter transference, prevention of 'emotional burnout,'

- personal growth.

SUPERVISOR_DESC.TITLE: Overview
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH1:
Status description

A PPL-certified supervising BG leader is allowed to conduct and document training hours of the Balint group participants to be considered in issuing the following types of certificates:
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH1_1: Basics of Balint group work - 36-40 hours
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH1_2: Balint group training for self-awareness and professional development. Basic course -72 hours
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH1_3: Balint group leaders’ training. Theory and practice of Balint group work. One-year course; 6 double seminars held once in 2 months - 96 hours
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH1_4: Supervision of the Balint group leaders’ training, participation in a special program for Balint work supervisors
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH2: Minimal requirements for the PPL-certified supervising BG leader candidate:
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH2_1: 8 years’ professional experience (as a psychotherapist, consulting psychologist, doctor, social worker, educator); 250 hours of personal therapy, full course of the Balint group leader training; consulting psychologists and psychotherapists  are required additional 3000 hours of psychotherapeutic practice and 250 hours of individual and group supervision
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH2_2: A minimum of 3 years of professional experience as a PPL-certified Balint group leader
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH2_3: At least 9 months (out of a year) of documented experience of conducting Balint groups for a minimum of once a month
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH2_4: 5 supervisions of a personal practice of Balint work a year
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH2_5: 3 supervisory seminars in mixed Russian-German groups in German Balint Society and PPL
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH3: Procedure for granting the PPL-certified supervising BG leader status:
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH3_1: The status is granted by the PPL Committee for Personal Therapy and Balint Movement
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH3_2: The contender should submit an application for the PPL-certified supervising BG leader containing a documented list of professional targets met
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH3_3: In case of the Committee’s positive decision to grant the status, the contender receives the status of a PPL-certified supervising BG leader of the approved model. The specialist’s personal data is further included in the PPL Balint Group Leaders’ Register and gets published on the PPL official website; the specialist covers the fee for retaining the data on the register
SUPERVISOR_DESC.PARAGRAPH3_4: The status is granted for a term period of 5 years, the status can be further extended following the application of the specialist and a corresponding decision of the PPL Committee for Personal Therapy and Balint Movement

HOME.NEWS:
Moscow Balint Society was admitted to the International Balint Federation!

The decision was taken at the International Balint Federation board meeting on May 26, 2018 (Reims, France).

OUR_HISTORY.TITLE: About Us

TEXT.1: The Balint movement has long been an integral part of professional culture among specialists in helping professions in developed countries, and their openness to Balint work has become an indicator of their level of professionalism. The positive impact of Balint work on the quality of professional relations in the field of helping professions is unquestionable in the scientific community.
TEXT.2: The Balint movement is currently gaining popularity in Russia. Aware of their social and professional responsibility, members of Moscow Balint Society consider it important to base their work on the principles of scientificity, openness and legitimacy.
TEXT.3: The Moscow Balint Society was founded on August 3, 2017 (the record of a non-profit organization was included in Russia’s Unified State Register of Legal Entities on August 3, 2017; state registration number: 117770012379) as a public non-profit organization for assistance to doctors, psychologists, medical and social workers, acting in accordance with the organization Statute under the authority of the organization Board.
TEXT.4: The Moscow Balint Society is guided by the high professional and ethical standards of the Balint work, described in the Statute and Regulations on Balint Group leadership of the International Balint Federation (IBF).
TEXT.5: The Moscow Balint Society goals are: professional training of BG leaders, dissemination of the Balint ideas and knowledge among the professional community at large, promotion of Balint work in accordance with the requirement of the International Balint Federation (IBF).
TEXT.6: Russian translation of Dr. Heide Otten’s The Theory and Practice of Balint Group Work: Analyzing Professional Relationships

Regional  public  organization  of  physicians,  psychologists,  medical  and  social  workers “•Balint Society in the city of Moscow” (hereinafter referred to as the Organization) is a nonprofit corporate organization established in the form of a public organization, a voluntary association of citizens united in the order established by the legislation, who have united on the basis of the generality of their interests for satisfaction of spiritual and other nonmaterial values, specified in this charter , which operates on the territory of the city of Moscow...
